title: No soft landing for returning expats
text:
The research was commissioned by job site Indeed, in partnership with Advance, an organisation set up in 2002 to work with the government to leverage the experience and connections of Australians living overseas.

A third of 440 so-called “repats” – Australians returning home after living abroad – who were surveyed regret coming home, saying they have struggled to have their skills recognised. And two-thirds have considered leaving Australia again.

Cheong-Holdaway, his wife and daughter returned to Melbourne, where he consulted (mainly by living on a plane) for a year before he took a job at Jemena at half his previous salary, and several rungs below his last position.

“One of the hardest things for me was updating my LinkedIn profile to energy analyst. I was an analyst a decade ago … to be one again was a knock to the ego,” he says, although he is backing himself to jump a few rungs faster than most.

Yasmin Allen says companies need to do a better job of supporting returning expatriates. Louie Douvis

Of the more than 1 million Australians living and working overseas, almost half return home within five years.

Yasmin Allen, who chairs Advance and is a non-executive director of companies, including Santos, Cochlear and the ASX, says expats are an underused economic resource, whether they are overseas or trying to return home.

Allen, who worked in Britain before coming home as an aviation analyst when Qantas Airways was privatised, says companies need to do a better job of supporting expatriates when they return. But equally, people returning home need to make sure they are plugged into Australia. “Your network does matter, but not to [the exclusion of] all else,” she says. “Of course your experience and background is important.

“There will always be trade-offs when employing people. Not everyone will exhibit all the desired skills and attributes. Maybe it’s about being more aware of that – if companies are aware of a weakness, they could backfill to reduce the risk.”

Keeping in touch with her networks at home helped Allen land a job in Australia. She left Britain after being put forward for an analyst role by a former colleague, one of the group of people she contacted each year when she returned for holidays in Australia.

However there are some jobs, she says, including those at a chief executive level, that benefit from people who bring career networks along with them.

“One important benefit of a CEO is the strong network they can attract to the organisation. Look at Santos, for example – good people follow CEOs in. I do think your network does matter, depending on the role.”

Like Allen, AsiaLink chief executive Penny Burtt says keeping in touch with her network was crucial to landing the type of job she had sought.

Asialink CEO Penny Burtt says she had to grapple with a perception she had come home to "retire". Supplied

“I landed very well because I was very deliberate about what would best suit my mindset and capabilities,” Burtt says. “It is absolutely essential to stay in touch. A lot of expats forget they have to stay in touch.”

When Burtt returned to Australia, she was at a different point in her career from Allen and Cheong-Holdaway. She had worked as a diplomat for two decades, serving in Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and Geneva, then held senior roles at McKinsey & Company and at Visa.

But Burtt, who has been home for about 12 months, says she has had to grapple with a perception she has come home to “retire”, rather than – as she sees it – building out her experience.

She was also surprised by the focus that one interview placed on her early Australian experience, rather than more recent roles.

According to the Indeed survey, recruiters are put off by job applications that assume any knowledge of offshore roles, especially by using little-known acronyms.

Katherine Chapman, a 51-year-old lawyer who returned to Australia with her husband and two children after 18 years offshore, says she has felt like a “square peg in a round hole” because her CV, which includes heading multinational law firm Freshfields’ practice management in Hong Kong, doesn’t tick the boxes for local recruiters.

“People are quite nervous if they haven’t done a stint outside of Australia,” she says.

Chapman, who came home about six months ago, expected the re-entry to be challenging, but says it has been harder than she and her husband, who is also a lawyer, expected.

“I think flexibility is the key when you’re a repat: for work, travel, hours,” she says, adding that she has restarted her business advisory company while continuing to look for a legal role.

Katherine Chapman returned to Australia six months ago after 18 years away, and was surprised at how much the work culture had changed. Paul Harris

Chapman says she was surprised by how much the Australian workplace culture had changed – for the better, she says – and by how few companies were prepared to gamble that she would adapt quickly to changes in cultural nuances.

“A lot of the repats really kind of give up after the six months and really struggle,” she says. “Once you get past the first hurdle and have more conversations and start to build your network, then life’s great. It’s a fantastic, dynamic workplace in Australia now.”

Burtt suspects any worries recruiters have about recommending expats for a role can be overcome when they meet a candidate.

That belief comes through in the research: while recruiters do see expats as a risky hire, nine out of 10 believe they bring cultural diversity and a thorough understanding of Australian workplace culture to the roles.

“I think there is a gap between reality and perception,” Burtt says. “And the prejudice can often vanish when they meet people and see there is real value.”

Cheong-Holdaway says it is up to the returning expat. “I feel like if you really want to commit to being back in Australia, you’ve got to back yourself,” he says. “You can’t really expect a company to bet on you being able to establish those relationships. I’m backing myself to skip a bunch of levels.”
description: New research confirms the widely held view that Australian companies are locking out workers returning from overseas.
